THE CITY OF SALISBURY WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 
3/28/14

1.	The City of Salisbury Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) has developed an Emergency Response Plan which complies with OSHA's 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management standard and the US EPA's Emergency Response Plan.  The plan provides employees guidance on what to do in case of a chemical discharge emergency.  

	
	In the event of a leak, the Salisbury Fire Department will be contacted to provide Haz - Mat Team response.  The LEPC will be contacted as well. 
	WWTP Leadership/personnel will act as liaison to the FD Command and Control.  
	All other WWTP personnel will be evacuated.   

2.	The City of Salisbury WWTP now treats approximately 5.0 million gallons per day of wastewater.  
	
3.  A review of the offsite consequence Worse Case Scenario analysis for chlorine and sulfur dioxide, utilizing RMP * Comp Ver. 1.07 resulted in the following:

4.	The leak detectors are still fully functional, giving audible and light alarms.  

5.	The status of the various components of the facility general accidental release prevention program is as follows:
	The preventive maintenance program documentation continues to be improved.	
	The leak detectors within the Chlorination/Dechlorination building are calibrated by a qualified service company quarterly. 
	The WWTP staff continues to be skilled, working with new personnel in a team approach.  As stated previously, training will be brought to up to a proper level, with associated documentation. 
	Standard Operating Procedures, including transferring and changing cylinders has been formulated and instituted.  
	A process safety management and risk management audit was performed by the Wicomico County Emergency services on August 19, 2013.	There have been no reportable accidental releases of chlorine or sulfur dioxide, at the WWTP, since the initial RMP/PSM Plan submittal. 

7.  The following changes to improve safety for ourselves and the community have been accomplished:
	A documentation form for cylinder hoist inspection has been instituted.
	Replacement of the tank flexible feed lines once per year. The chemical dispensing equipment and chemical distribution lines were replaced with new equipment in the summer of 2012. 
	A permanent water feed line was installed, serving the Chlorination/Dechlorination Building.

	
8.	The Chlorination/Dechlorination system will be removed from service at some future date as it is scheduled to be replaced by an Ultra Violet disinfection system in the next Waste Water Plant  upgrade.
